TITLE: Defining and Using a Custom Error Type in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet demonstrates the correct way to define and use a custom error type using the `type!` keyword. The String type is wrapped within a `StringError` error type, which can then be used after the '!' in the function's return type and can be raised within the function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4127.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type! StringError String

pub fn may_raise_error() -> Unit!StringError {
  raise StringError("Failed")
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Struct Initialization and Field Access in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to initialize a struct using a struct literal in MoonBit. Also, shows how to access and modify struct fields using dot syntax. Note the use of `mut` keyword to make fields mutable.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_72

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  var p = Person { name: "Alice", age: 30, email: "alice@example.com" }
  debug(p.name)
  debug(p.age)
  debug(p.email)

  struct MutablePerson {
    name : String
    age : Int
    mut email : String
  }

  var mp = MutablePerson { name: "Bob", age: 25, email: "bob@example.com" }
  mp.email = "bob.new@example.com"
  debug(mp.email)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Generics in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates defining a generic list data type and functions in MoonBit. It includes the definition of a generic `List` enum and functions `map` and `reduce`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_104

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum List[T] {
  Nil,
  Cons(T, List[T]),
}

fn map[T, U](list: List[T], f: Fn(T) -> U) -> List[U] {
  match list {
    Nil => Nil,
    Cons(head, tail) => Cons(f(head), map(tail, f)),
  }
}

fn reduce[T, U](list: List[T], initial: U, f: Fn(U, T) -> U) -> U {
  match list {
    Nil => initial,
    Cons(head, tail) => f(reduce(tail, initial, f), head),
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Importing Foreign Function in MoonBit (Wasm/Wasm GC)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to import a foreign function in MoonBit for the Wasm and Wasm GC backends. It shows how to specify the module name and function name from the runtime host.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/ffi.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn cos(d : Double) -> Double = "math" "cos"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using the Error Type in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the usage of the built-in `Error` type in MoonBit. It shows how to define functions that can raise errors, how to catch errors using `try...catch`, and how to handle specific error types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_24

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// These signatures are equivalent. They all raise Error.
fn f() -> Unit! { .. }
fn f!() -> Unit { .. }
fn f() -> Unit!Error { .. }

fn test_error() -> Result[Int, Error] {
  fn f() -> _!_ {
    raise DivisionByZeroError("err")
  }

  try {
    Ok(f!())
  } catch {
    err => Err(err)
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Enum Pattern Matching Example in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates pattern matching with enums in MoonBit. It shows how to construct enum values and use `case` statements to determine which enum case a value belongs to.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_77

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn print_color(color : Color) {
  case color {
    Red => debug("Red")
    Green => debug("Green")
    Blue => debug("Blue")
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Bash: Install MoonBit toolchain
DESCRIPTION: This script installs the MoonBit toolchain on Linux and macOS systems. It downloads the installation script and executes it using bash, placing MoonBit in `$HOME/.moon` and adding it to the PATH.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/tutorial/tour.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
curl -fsSL https://cli.moonbitlang.com/install/unix.sh | bash
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Traits in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to implement a trait for a type using the `impl Trait for Type with method_name(...) { ... }` syntax.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start trait 2
trait Foo {
  fn bar(self : Self) -> Int
}

impl Foo for Int with bar(self) {
  self + 1
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Simple Pattern Matching in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates basic pattern matching in MoonBit, including matching against literals and binding values to identifiers. The `match` expression checks the value of `x` and binds it to `y` if it's 1, or uses wildcard `_` if it doesn't care about the value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_93

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f(x : Int) -> Int {
  match x {
    1 => { 1 }
    _ => { 0 }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Newtypes to Avoid Type Alias Cycles in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the recommended way to avoid type alias cycles by using newtypes. By defining both A and B as new types using `type A B` and `type B A`, we avoid the circular dependency that causes the E4129 error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4129.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type A B
type B A
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining a Type Alias in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the definition of a type alias in MoonBit using the `typealias` keyword. A type alias does not create a new type but acts as a type macro, behaving identically to its definition.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_91

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
typealias I = Int
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Extending Traits in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how a trait can depend on other traits, requiring implementers to also satisfy the dependencies.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start super trait 1
trait Foo {
  fn bar(self : Self) -> Int
}

trait Bar: Foo {
  fn baz(self : Self) -> Int
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: try/catch with Simple Expression
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the short hand syntax for try/catch blocks where the body is a single expression and the catch keyword is omitted.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  try
    f!() catch
    MyError => println("caught MyError")
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Accessing Array Elements in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to access array elements using their index within square brackets.  The index starts at 0.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_23

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
numbers[x]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Matching Error Types in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to perform exhaustive matching on the `Error` type using a `match` statement.  It demonstrates how to handle specific error types like `DivisionByZeroError` and provides a catch-all case `_`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_25

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type! ArithmeticError

fn what_error_is_this(e : Error) -> Unit {
  match e {
    DivisionByZeroError(_) => println("DivisionByZeroError")
    ArithmeticError => println("ArithmeticError")
    ... => println("...")
    _ => println("Error")
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Deriving Hash for Structs in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to derive the `Hash` trait for a struct in MoonBit. The generated `Hash` implementation allows the struct to be used as a key in hash-based data structures like `HashMap` and `HashSet`. All fields within the struct must also implement the `Hash` trait.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/derive.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct Point { x: Int; y: Int } derive(Hash)

fn main() {
  // Example usage with HashMap would go here
  // but HashMap is not directly shown in this snippet
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pipe Operator Usage in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the use of the pipe operator `|>` in MoonBit. It allows chaining function calls by passing the result of one function as the first argument to the next function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_105

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn add1(x : Int) -> Int { x + 1 }
fn mul2(x : Int) -> Int { x * 2 }

fn main {
  let result = 5 |> add1 |> mul2
  debug(result) // Output: 12
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Tuple in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to define a tuple in MoonBit. A tuple is a collection of finite values constructed using round brackets `()` with the elements separated by commas `,`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  let tuple : (Int, Bool, String) = (1, true, "hello")
  println(tuple)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Enum with Payload Data in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates an enum definition where cases carry payload data. The example uses an integer list type to demonstrate this concept.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_79

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum IntList {
  Nil
  Cons(head : Int, tail : IntList)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Sub Traits in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates implementing a sub-trait, requiring implementation of both the sub-trait's methods and the methods of any super-traits it depends on.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start super trait 2
trait Foo {
  fn bar(self : Self) -> Int
}

trait Bar: Foo {
  fn baz(self : Self) -> Int
}

impl Bar for Int with bar(self), baz(self) {
  self + 1
}

```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Optional Arguments in MoonBit (Dependency)
DESCRIPTION: This code shows that the default expression for an optional argument can depend on the value of previous arguments. This allows creating flexible argument defaults.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_41

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn range(start : Int, end~ : Int = start + 10) {
  // ...
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Optional Arguments in MoonBit (Declaration)
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to define optional arguments in MoonBit using the syntax `label~ : Type = default_expr`. If the argument is not supplied, the default expression is used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_38

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn greet(name~ : String = "World") {
  IO::println("Hello, " ++ name ++ "!")
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Deriving Show for Structs in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to derive the `Show` trait for a struct in MoonBit. The `Show` trait generates a pretty-printing method for the type, which displays the struct's fields and their values. All fields within the struct must also implement the `Show` trait.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/derive.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct Point { x: Int; y: Int } derive(Show)

fn main() {
  let p = Point { x: 1, y: 2 }
  println("{}", p) // prints "Point { x: 1, y: 2 }"
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Function with Error Type
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define a function that can return an error of a specific type. It uses the `raise` keyword to return an error value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type! DivError String
fn div(x : Int, y : Int) -> Int!DivError {
  if y == 0 {
    raise DivError("division by zero")
  }
  x / y
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using 'let' for Initialization in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to use the `let` keyword in MoonBit as an alternative to `const` when the value needs to be computed at initialization time. The expression `1 + 1` is evaluated during program startup, and the result is assigned to the variable `a`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4142.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
let a : Int = 1 + 1 // These will be computed at initialization time.
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Error Handling on Method Invocation
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the `!` and `?` attributes on method invocations and the pipe operator for error handling.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
x.foo!()
x.foo?()
x |> foo!()
x |> foo?()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Importing Foreign Function in MoonBit (C)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to import a foreign function from a C library in MoonBit.  The `extern "C"` keyword is used, and the function name is specified.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/ffi.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
extern "C" fn put_char(ch : UInt) = "function_name"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: `main` Function Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a `main` function in MoonBit, which serves as the entry point of the program and gets executed after initialization. It demonstrates a basic `main` function that binds a value to a local variable and prints it. Only `main` packages can define a `main` function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/introduction.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  let x = 2
  println(x)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Trait Declaration in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to declare a trait in MoonBit, defining a list of operations that a type must implement to satisfy the trait.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start trait 1
trait Foo {
  fn bar(self : Self) -> Int
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: `for .. in` Loop in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This example shows a basic `for .. in` loop in MoonBit, which is used to iterate over elements of a data structure. The standard library's `Iter` trait facilitates this.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_62

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
for elem in collection {
  // process elem
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Method Call Syntax in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the difference in calling methods defined using the two syntaxes. Methods defined with `fn method_name(self : T, ..)` can be invoked directly like regular functions, while those defined with `fn T::method_name(..)` must be invoked using the qualified syntax `T::method_name(..)`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// Method call syntax example
fn f(self : Foo) -> Int {
  1
}

fn main {
  let foo = Foo {}
  f(foo) // call method f
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: try/catch with omitted else block
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use try/catch where the else block is omitted.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error-handling.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  try {
    f!()
  } catch {
    MyError => println("caught MyError")
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Main Package Configuration (main/moon.pkg.json)
DESCRIPTION: Configures the `main` package to be linked into a WASM file and specifies its dependencies. The `is_main: true` flag indicates that this package should be built into an executable.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/toolchain/moon/tutorial.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "is_main": true,
  "import": [
    "username/hello/lib"
  ]
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: MoonBit: Implement count_qualified_students with iterator
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the `count_qualified_students` function in MoonBit using iterator functions. It filters the array of students using the `is_qualified` function and then counts the remaining students, providing a concise functional approach.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/tutorial/tour.md#_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn count_qualified_students(
  students : Array[Student],
  is_qualified : (Student) -> ExamResult
) -> Int {
  students.iter().filter(fn(student) { is_qualified(student) == Pass }).count()
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Calling Constrained Generic Functions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example of calling a constrained generic function with a type that implements the required trait, in this case, `Eq`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start trait 6
trait Eq[Self] {
  fn eq(self : Self, other : Self) -> Bool
}

impl Eq[Int] for Int with eq(self, other) {
  self == other
}

fn main {
  let arr = [1, 2, 3]
  contains(arr, 1)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Option and Result in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to define Option and Result in MoonBit. `Option` and `Result` are the most common types to represent a possible error or failure in MoonBit.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_21

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
let option : Int? = none
let result : Result[Int, String] = Ok(10)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing `op_add` for Infix Operator in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the correct implementation of the `op_add` method for the struct `S`, enabling the use of the `+` infix operator. The `op_add` method takes two instances of `S` as input and returns a new instance of `S` with the sum of their `v` fields.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4016.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct S { v : Int }

let s : S = { v: 3 }
let t = s + s

fn S::op_add(self : S, other : S) -> S {
  { v: self.v + other.v }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining WordSize Trait and Implementations in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the `WordSize` trait with a `word_size()` method that returns an `Int`. It provides implementations of the `WordSize` trait for `Float` and `Double`, specifying the word size for each type. The `WordSize` trait and its implementations are used to demonstrate the trait constraint issue.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4135.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait WordSize { word_size() -> Int }
impl WordSize for Float with word_size() { 1 }
impl WordSize for Double with word_size() { 2 }
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Constrained Generic Functions with Traits in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates declaring a generic function with type parameters constrained by traits, ensuring the type parameters implement specific traits.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start trait 5
fn contains[T: Eq](arr : Array[T], elem : T) -> Bool {
  for x in arr {
    if x == elem { return true }
  }
  return false
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating and Extracting Newtype Values in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates creating a newtype value and extracting its underlying representation using pattern matching. The `main` function creates an instance of the newtype `T` and then extracts the `Int` value contained within it using pattern matching.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_89

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  let x = T(10)
  match x {
    T(y) => { debug(y) }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Calling Async Functions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to call an async function in MoonBit using the `!` operator. It highlights that the `!` operator will rethrow errors if the async function may throw an error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/async-experimental.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
let name = await get_name!()
let greeting = await hello!(name)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Deriving Eq and Compare for Enums in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows deriving the `Eq` and `Compare` traits for an enum in MoonBit. The generated methods allow for checking equality and ordering between different enum variants. The order of enum cases is determined by their definition order.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/derive.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum Order {
  Less
  Equal
  Greater
} derive(Eq, Compare)

fn main() {
  println("{}", Less == Less)    // prints "true"
  println("{}", Less == Greater) // prints "false"
  println("{}", Less < Greater)   // prints "true"
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Enum Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Shows the definition of an enum type in MoonBit. Enums are similar to algebraic data types and can have multiple cases (constructors). Constructor names must start with a capitalized letter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_76

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum Color {
  Red
  Green
  Blue
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Corrected Generic Type Definitions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet shows two possible corrections for the error E4000. The first example renames the duplicate type variable 'T' in the 'Container' struct to 'T1' and 'T2'. The 'transform' function is updated to use 'A' and 'B'. The second example demonstrates that if the intention was to use the same type, the duplicate type parameter can be removed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4000.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct Container[T1, T2] {
  value : T1
}

fn transform[A, B](x : A) -> B {
  // ... implementation
}
```

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct Container[T] {
  value : T
}

fn transform[A](x : A) -> A {
  x
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: C Callback Registration with MoonBit Closure
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code shows how to bind a C function that accepts a callback and extra data, and how to pass a MoonBit closure to it.  It defines a `register_callback_ffi` function using `extern "C"` to bind to the C function and uses `FuncRef` to pass a closed MoonBit function.  The `register_callback` function then calls `register_callback_ffi` with a lambda that invokes the callback, thus effectively passing the original callback as a closure.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/ffi.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
extern "C" fn register_callback_ffi(
  call_closure : FuncRef[(() -> Unit) -> Unit],
  closure : () -> Unit
) = "register_callback"

fn register_callback(callback : () -> Unit) -> Unit {
  register_callback_ffi(
    fn (f) { f() },
    callback
  )
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Trait Object Example
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to pack methods of a type that implements a trait into a runtime object using `as &I` syntax in MoonBit. This enables runtime polymorphism.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait Foo {
  bar(Self) -> Int
}

struct A {}
impl Foo for A {
  fn bar(self: Self) -> Int { 1 }
}

struct B {}
impl Foo for B {
  fn bar(self: Self) -> Int { 2 }
}

fn main() {
  let a: A = A{};
  let b: B = B{};

  let arr: Array<&Foo> = Array::new(2);
  arr[0] = &a;
  arr[1] = &b;
  {
    let i = 0;
    while i < arr.length() {
      debug(arr[i].bar())
      i = i + 1
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Access Control Examples
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates access control rules in MoonBit, showing how private types (`priv`) affect the visibility of fields in public structs and the parameters/return types of public functions.  Highlights the restrictions to avoid exposing private types via public entities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/packages.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub(all) type T1
pub(all) type T2
priv type T3

pub(all) struct S {
  x: T1  // OK
  y: T2  // OK
  z: T3  // ERROR: public field has private type `T3`!
}

// ERROR: public function has private parameter type `T3`!
pub fn f1(_x: T3) -> T1 { ... }
// ERROR: public function has private return type `T3`!
pub fn f2(_x: T1) -> T3 { ... }
// OK
pub fn f3(_x: T1) -> T1 { ... }

pub let a: T3 = { ... } // ERROR: public variable has private type `T3`!
```

TITLE: Trait Example
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the definition and implementation of a trait in MoonBit. It showcases how traits can define interfaces and how different types can implement those interfaces. It also illustrates that abstract traits have limited visibility from outside the defining package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/packages.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait Number {
 op_add(Self, Self) -> Self
 op_sub(Self, Self) -> Self
}

fn add[N : Number](x : N, y: N) -> N {
  Number::op_add(x, y)
}

fn sub[N : Number](x : N, y: N) -> N {
  Number::op_sub(x, y)
}

impl Number for Int with op_add(x, y) { x + y }
impl Number for Int with op_sub(x, y) { x - y }

impl Number for Double with op_add(x, y) { x + y }
impl Number for Double with op_sub(x, y) { x - y }
```

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait Number

fn op_add[N : Number](x : N, y : N) -> N
fn op_sub[N : Number](x : N, y : N) -> N

impl Number for Int
impl Number for Double
```

TITLE: For-Loop with 'else' Branch (Solution)
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to resolve the E4108 error by adding an 'else' branch to the for-loop. The 'else' branch specifies the value to be returned when the loop completes normally. The value returned in the `else` branch in this case is the accumulated value `acc`.

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int) -> Int {
  for i = 0, acc = 0; i < x; i = i + 1, acc = acc + i {
  } else {
    acc
  }
}
```

TITLE: Sliding Stack Elements in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet implements the `Slide` instruction.  The `Slide(n)` instruction skips the first address on the stack and then removes the next N addresses. It's used to clean up addresses of local variables in `let` and `letrec` expressions that are no longer needed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
Slide(n: Int),

    Slide(n) => {
      let addr = state.stack.last()
      let new_stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)
      let new_stack = list::drop(new_stack, n)
      {state with stack = list::push(new_stack, addr)}
    }
```

TITLE: Checking for Single Possible Value in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This function checks if a list contains only one element. If the list is empty, it returns `Err(false)`. If the list contains a single element `x`, it returns `Ok(x)`. If the list contains more than one element, it returns `Err(true)`. This function is used in the `eliminate` function to determine if a square has only one possible value left.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
// Return `Err(false)` if the list is empty
// Return `Ok(x)` if the list contains only `[x]`
// Return `Err(true)` if the list contains `[x1, x2, ......]`
fn single[T](this : List[T]) -> Result[T, Bool] {
  match this {
    Nil => Err(false)
    Cons(x, Nil) => Ok(x)
    _ => Err(true)
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Arithmetic Operations in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code defines helper functions for implementing binary operations. The op function takes two addresses from the stack, evaluates them to NNum nodes, performs the operation, and pushes the result back onto the stack.  It handles potential errors by returning the original state if the nodes are not NNum.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn op(state : GState, f : Fn(Int, Int) -> Int) -> GState {
  let (a1, a2) = state.pop2()
  let state = {state with stack = list::push(state.stack, a2)}
  let state = eval(state)
  let a2 = state.stack.last()
  let state = {state with stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)}

  let state = {state with stack = list::push(state.stack, a1)}
  let state = eval(state)
  let a1 = state.stack.last()
  let state = {state with stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)}

  match (state.heap[a1], state.heap[a2]) {
    (Node::NNum(n1), Node::NNum(n2)) => {
      let newnode = Node::NNum(f(n1, n2))
      let addr = state.heap.alloc(newnode)
      {
        state with
        stack = list::push(state.stack, addr)
      }
    }
    _ => state
  }
}

TITLE: Substitution Function for TermDBI in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet implements the `subst` function for substituting a `TermDBI` into another `TermDBI` at a given depth in MoonBit. It recursively traverses the target term, replacing variables at the specified depth with the substitution term. The `subst` function is a key component of beta reduction in the Lambda calculus interpreter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/lambda/index.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn subst(self : TermDBI, depth : Int, term : TermDBI) -> TermDBI {
  match self {
    VarDBI(i, s) => {
      if i == depth {
        term
      } else if i > depth {
        VarDBI(i - 1, s)
      } else {
        self
      }
    }
    AbsDBI(varname, body) => {
      AbsDBI(varname, subst(body, depth + 1, term))
    }
    AppDBI(t1, t2) => {
      AppDBI(subst(t1, depth, term), subst(t2, depth, term))
    }
  }
}
```

fn async_timer() -> String:
  let result = %async.suspend[String]((cb: Result[fn(String), fn(Error)]) => {
    match cb {
      Ok(resume_ok) => {
        setTimeout(() => {
          resume_ok("Timer expired!")
        }, 1000)
      }
      Err(resume_err) => {
        resume_err(Error::new("Timer cancelled!"))
      }
    }
  })
  result
```

TITLE: Overloading `op_as_view` for Custom View in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to implement `op_as_view` method for creating a view for user-defined type, allowing to implement slicing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/methods.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// start view 2
fn Array::op_as_view(self : Array[T], start? : Option[Int], end? : Option[Int]) -> Array[T] {
  let start = match start? {
    None => 0
    Some(v) => v
  }
  let end = match end? {
    None => len(self.data)
    Some(v) => v
  }
  let view = Array { data : [] }
  for i = start; i < end; i = i + 1 {
    view.data.push(self[i])
  }
  view
}
```

}

TITLE: Take Function for Stream in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `take` function for `Stream` in MoonBit. It extracts the first `n` elements from the stream, forcing computation. The function returns a regular `List[T]` containing the extracted elements.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn take[T](self : Stream[T], n : Int) -> List[T] {
  if n == 0 {
    Nil
  } else {
    match self {
      Empty => Nil
      Cons(x, xs) => Cons(x, xs().take(n - 1))
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Querying Segment Tree in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet implements the `query` function for a segment tree in MoonBit.  It takes the root of the segment tree and a query range (query_l, query_r) as input and returns the sum of the elements in the specified range.  If the query range does not overlap with the current range (l, r), it returns an empty node.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn query(root : Node, l : Int, r : Int, query_l : Int, query_r : Int) -> Node {
  let empty_node : Node = Nil
  if query_l > r || query_r < l {
    empty_node
  } else if query_l <= l && query_r >= r {
    root
  } else {
    match root {
      Nil => empty_node
      Node(_, left, right) => {
        let mid = l + (r - l) / 2
        let left_result = query(left, l, mid, query_l, query_r)
        let right_result = query(right, mid + 1, r, query_l, query_r)
        op_add(left_result, right_result)
      }
    }
  }
}

```

TITLE: Finding Index Depth in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines a helper function to find the corresponding `depth` based on a specific `name` from an immutable list of `Index` structs. The function recursively searches the list for a matching name and returns its depth or an error if not found. This helper function aids in the `bruijn` conversion process.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/lambda/index.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// Find the depth of a name in the index list
fn find_depth(name : String, index : @immut/list.T[Index]) -> Result[Int, String] {
  fn go(name : String, index : @immut/list.T[Index]) -> Result[Int, String] {
    match index {
      Nil => Err("find_depth(): Name not found: \{"name}"")
      Cons(head, tail) => {
        if head.name == name {
          Ok(head.depth)
        } else {
          go(name, tail)
        }
      }
    }
  }
  go(name, index)
}
```

TITLE: Unicode-Safe String Palindrome Check in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a unicode-safe way to check if a string is a palindrome using array pattern matching in MoonBit. The string is matched against a pattern that checks if the first and last characters are equal, and recursively calls the function on the remaining string view.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_97

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn is_palindrome(s : String) -> Bool {
  match s.view {
    [] => true
    [a,.._,b] => a == b && is_palindrome(s.view.slice(1, s.length - 1).to_string)
    [a] => true
  }
}
```

TITLE: Labelled Loop with Continue/Break in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the usage of labelled loops in MoonBit, enabling control flow from nested loops using `break` and `continue` statements with labels. This example shows how to exit or continue specific outer loops from within inner loops.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_68

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main() {
  loop out(x : Int) : Int {
    loop in(y : Int) : Int {
      case x + y > 10 => break out x + y
      case y > 3 => continue in y - 1
      case _ => continue in y + 1
    }
    case _ => break out 0
  }
}
```

TITLE: Handling d = 0, k = 0 case in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code handles the base case where the edit distance `d` is 0 and `k` is 0. It skips over matching lines at the beginning of both input arrays and updates the `v` array with the final `x` coordinate.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
if d == 0 { // When d equals 0, k must also equal 0
  x = 0
  y = x - k
  while x < n && y < m && old[x].text == new[y].text {
    // Skip all matching lines
    x = x + 1
    y = y + 1
  }
  v[k] = x
}

```

TITLE: MoonBit: MkApp Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `MkApp` instruction. It pops two addresses from the stack (representing the function and argument), creates a new `NApp` node in the heap pointing to these two addresses, and pushes the address of this new `NApp` node onto the stack. This effectively constructs a function application node.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn mk_apply(s : GState) -> GState {
    match s.stack {
      Nil => { abort("Stack underflow") }
      Cons(arg_addr, rest) => {
        match rest {
          Nil => { abort("Stack underflow") }
          Cons(fun_addr, new_stack) => {
            let addr = new_addr(s.heap)
            let new_heap = { nodes = array_set(s.heap.nodes, addr, { app = (fun_addr, arg_addr) }) }
            { s with heap = new_heap, stack = cons(addr, new_stack) }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: Corrected MoonBit For-Loop: Initialization Block
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to fix the E4106 error by declaring the variable `j` in the initialization block of the for-loop. The function `f` now initializes both `i` and `j` within the `for` statement, resolving the error. It iterates and prints the values of `i` and `j`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4106.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int) -> Unit {
   for i = 0, j = 0; i < x; i = i + 1, j = j + 1 {
    println(i)
    println(j)
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Range Modifications in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the range modification function. It's similar to a query function but applies the necessary LazyTag for the modification to each relevant node. The function returns a newly created segment tree without modifying the original one, demonstrating the persistent or immutable nature of the implementation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree2.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn modify[Data: Op_add[Data, Tag] + Op_add_tag[Data, Tag], Tag: Op_add_tag[Data, Tag]](node: Node[Data, Tag], l: Int, r: Int, ql: Int, qr: Int, tag: Tag) -> Node[Data, Tag] {
  if ql <= l && qr >= r {
    return apply(node, tag)
  }
  if qr < l || ql > r {
    return node
  }

  match node {
    Leaf(_) => node
    Node { left, right, data, tag: old_tag, len } => {
      // Propagate tag to children
      let left = apply(left, old_tag)
      let right = apply(right, old_tag)

      let mid = l + (r - l) / 2
      let left = modify(left, l, mid, ql, qr, tag)
      let right = modify(right, mid + 1, r, ql, qr, tag)

      Node { left, right, data: op_add(left, right), tag: Nil, len }
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Read-Only Struct Example
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the use of `pub` for read-only structs in MoonBit, showing how they can be accessed within the defining package and the restrictions on construction and mutation from other packages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/packages.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// Package A
pub struct RO {
  field: Int
}
test {
  let r = { field: 4 }       // OK
  let r = { ..r, field: 8 }  // OK
}

// Package B
fn println(r : RO) -> Unit {
  println("{ field: ")
  println(r.field)  // OK
  println(" }")
}
test {
  let r : RO = { field: 4 }  // ERROR: Cannot create values of the public read-only type RO!
  let r = { ..r, field: 8 }  // ERROR: Cannot mutate a public read-only field!
}
```

TITLE: Complete Diff Implementation in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides the complete diff implementation by combining the shortest edit distance calculation and backtracking to generate the edit sequence. It calculates and returns the complete difference between two sequences.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff2.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn diff[T: Eq](xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> List[Edit[T]] {
  let edits = backtrack_fst(xs, ys)
  let edits = backtrack_snd::remove_dup(edits)
  backtrack_snd::reverse(edits)
}
```

TITLE: Compiling Letrec Expressions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code compiles 'letrec' expressions.  It allocates N addresses using `Alloc(n)`, builds a complete environment using a `loop` expression, compiles the local variables in `defs` using the `Update` instruction to update the pre-allocated addresses, compiles the main expression, and uses `Slide` to clean up.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn compile_letrec(defs : List[(String, Core)], body : Core, comp : Fn(Core, Env) -> List[Instruction], env : Env) -> List[Instruction] {
  let n = list::length(defs)
  let alloc_instr = list::singleton(Instruction::Alloc(n))

  let new_env = list::fold_left(defs, env, (env, def) => {
    let name = def._1
    let new_env = map::insert(env, name, EnvValue::Addr(map::size(env)))
    new_env
  })
  let def_compiles = list::map(defs, (def) => compileC(def._2, new_env))
  let update_instrs = list::make_with_index(n, (i) => Instruction::Update(n - 1 - i))

  let body_compile = comp(body, new_env)
  let slide_instr = list::singleton(Instruction::Slide(n))

  list::append(list::append(list::append(list::append(alloc_instr, list::interleave(def_compiles, update_instrs)), body_compile), slide_instr)
  )
}
```

TITLE: Eliminating Value from a Square in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This function eliminates a possible value from a square and applies heuristic strategies to propagate the constraints. It takes a `SquareMap`, a square `key`, and a value `val` to eliminate. It checks if `val` exists in the square's possible values before attempting elimination. The function returns `true` if the elimination is successful and `false` if a contradiction occurs (i.e., the square has no possible values left).
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
fn eliminate(values : SquareMap[List[Char]], key : String, val : Char) -> Bool {
  if not(exist(values[key], fn (v) { v == val })) {
    return true
  }
  values[key] = values[key].remove(val)
  // If `key` has only one possible value left, remove this value from its peers
  match single(values[key]) {
    Err(b) => {
      if not(b) {
        return false
      }
    }
    Ok(val) => {
      let mut result = true
      peers[key].iter(fn (key) {
        result = result && eliminate(values, key, val)
      })
      if not(result) {
        return false
      }
    }
  }
  //  If there is only one square in the unit of `key` that can hold `val`, assign `val` to that square
  let unit = units[key]
  let places = unit.filter(fn (sq) {
    exist(values[sq], fn (v) { v == val })
  })
  match single(places) {
    Err(b) => {
      return b
    }
    Ok(key) => {
      return assign(values, key, val)
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Searching for Sudoku Solution in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This function searches for a solution to the Sudoku puzzle using a recursive backtracking algorithm. It takes a `SquareMap` representing the current state of the grid.  If there are no squares with more than one possible value, it means a solution has been found and returns `Some(values)`. Otherwise, it finds the square with the fewest possible values and tries each value recursively using `assign`. If a value leads to a contradiction, it backtracks and tries the next value.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
fn search(values : SquareMap[List[Char]]) -> Option[SquareMap[List[Char]]] {
  if values.contains(fn (digits){ not(isSingleton(digits)) }) {
    // // Find the square with the smallest number of possible values greater than 1, and start the search from this square
    // This is just a heuristic strategy; you can try finding a smarter and more effective one
    let mut minsq = ""
    let mut n = 10
    squares.iter(fn (sq) {
      let len = values[sq].length()
      if len > 1 {
        if len < n {
          n = len
          minsq = sq
        }
      }
    })
    // Iterate through assignments and stop if a successful search is found
    loop values[minsq] {
      Nil => None
      Cons(digit, rest) => {
        let another = values.copy()
        if assign(another, minsq, digit){
          match search(another) {
            None => continue rest
            Some(_) as result => result
          }
        } else {
          continue rest
        }
      }
    }
  } else {
    return Some(values)
  }
}
```

struct BPArray {
  arr : Array[Int]
  offset : Int
}

fn make(size : Int, initial : Int) -> BPArray {
  let arr = Array::make(size, initial)

}

  self.arr[index + self.offset]
}

fn set(mut self : BPArray, index : Int, value : Int) {
  self.arr[index + self.offset] = value
}

TITLE: Evaluation (Reduction) Function for TermDBI in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet implements the `eval` function for reducing `TermDBI` expressions in MoonBit. It performs beta reduction by evaluating the left-hand side of an `AppDBI` term. If the result is an `AbsDBI`, it substitutes the argument into the abstraction's body using the `subst` function and recursively evaluates the result. Lambdas are returned as is.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/lambda/index.md#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn eval(self : TermDBI) -> TermDBI {
  match self {
    AppDBI(t1, t2) => {
      let t1_reduced = eval(t1)
      let t2_reduced = eval(t2)
      match t1_reduced {
        AbsDBI(varname, body) => {
          eval(subst(body, 0, t2_reduced))
        }
        _ => AppDBI(t1_reduced, t2_reduced)
      }
    }
    AbsDBI(varname, body) => AbsDBI(varname, body)
    VarDBI(i, s) => VarDBI(i, s)
  }
}
```

TITLE: Building Segment Tree in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to build a segment tree from a linear sequence using MoonBit's `ArrayView`. It recursively divides the segment at the midpoint, builds left and right subtrees, and merges them using the `op_add` function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn build(arr : ArrayView[Int]) -> Node {
  let len = array::length(arr)
  if len == 1 {
    Node(arr[0], Nil, Nil)
  } else {
    let mid = len / 2
    let left = build(array::slice(arr, 0, mid))
    let right = build(array::slice(arr, mid, len))
    op_add(left, right)
  }
}

```

TITLE: Determining x Coordinate Based on k Value in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet determines the x coordinate based on the value of k and previous coordinates. It prioritizes deletions over insertions by choosing the path with the larger x value. Boundary conditions for k = -d and k = d are handled appropriately.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff.md#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
if k == -d {
  x = v[k + 1]
} else if k == d {
  x = v[k - 1] + 1 // add 1 to move horizontally
} else if v[k - 1] < v[k + 1] {
  x = v[k + 1]
} else {
  x = v[k - 1] + 1
}

```

TITLE: Defining LazyTag and Apply Function in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code defines the LazyTag type and the `apply` function, which is used to apply a LazyTag to a node. It defines how to merge existing LazyTags and how to compute the new value of the node based on the LazyTag and segment length. The crucial part is to compute the correct node's value with the segment's length and the value of LazyTag.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree2.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait Op_add_tag[Data, Tag] {
  fn op_add_tag(Tag, Tag) -> Tag
  fn apply(data: Data, tag: Tag, len: Int) -> Data
}

impl [Data: Op_add_tag[Data, Tag], Tag: Op_add_tag[Data, Tag]] Op_add_tag[Node[Data, Tag], Tag] for Node[Data, Tag] {
  fn op_add_tag(tag1: Tag, tag2: Tag) -> Tag {
    op_add_tag(tag1, tag2)
  }

  fn apply(node: Node[Data, Tag], tag: Tag) -> Node[Data, Tag] {
    match node {
      Leaf(data) => {
        let new_data = apply(data, tag, 1)
        Leaf(new_data)
      }
      Node { left, right, data, tag: old_tag, len } => {
        let new_tag = op_add_tag(old_tag, tag)
        let new_data = apply(data, new_tag, len)
        Node { left, right, data: new_data, tag: new_tag, len }
      }
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Constructor Arity Mismatch Example in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a constructor arity mismatch error within an enum definition. The constructor 'A' for enum 'E' requires three arguments (Int, Double, String), but it is called with two arguments in both the constructor call and the match arm, leading to the error. The code showcases the error occurring in both the construction and pattern matching of the enum variant.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4080.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum E {
  A(Int, Double, String)
}

fn main {
  match A(0, 1.0) { // Error: This function has type (Int, Double, String) -> E, which requires 3 arguments, but is given 2 arguments.
    A(_, _) => ... // Error: The constructor A requires 3 arguments, but is given 2 arguments.
  }
}
```

TITLE: Map Function for Stream in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Defines the `map` function for `Stream` in MoonBit. It applies a function `f` to each element of the stream lazily, wrapping the result in a new `Stream`. The mapping operation is deferred until the stream is actually consumed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn map[X, Y](self : Stream[X], f : (X) -> Y) -> Stream[Y] {
  match self {
    Empty => Empty
    Cons(x, xs) => Cons(f(x), fn () { xs().map(f) })
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using New Type to Resolve E4053 (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to resolve the E4053 error by wrapping the type with a 'new type' (using the `type` keyword), allowing it to be used with 'self'.  Demonstrates usage in function definitions and trait implementations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4053.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub(all) type Wrap[T] T

fn f[T](self : Wrap[T]) -> Int {
  ignore(self)
  0
}

fn g(self : Wrap[(Int) -> Unit]) -> Unit {
  (self._)(0)
}

impl[X] A for Wrap[X] with f(self : Wrap[X]) -> Int {
  ignore(self)
  0
}
```

TITLE: Complete Shortest Edit Function in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code presents the completed `shortest_edit` function, integrating the k-based coordinate logic and boundary conditions. The primary objective of this function is to determine the minimum number of edits needed to transform the 'old' array into the 'new' array.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff.md#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn shortest_edit(old~ : Array[Line], new~ : Array[Line]) -> Int {
  let n = old.length()
  let m = new.length()
  let max = n + m
  let v = BPArray::make(2 * max + 1, 0)
  for d = 0; d < max + 1; d = d + 1 {
    for k = -d; k < d + 1; k = k + 2 {
      let mut x = 0
      if k == -d || (k != d && v[k - 1] < v[k + 1]) {
        x = v[k + 1]
      } else {
        x = v[k - 1] + 1
      }
      let mut y = x - k

      while x < n && y < m && old[x].text == new[y].text {
        x = x + 1
        y = y + 1
      }

      v.set(k, x)
      if x == n && y == m {
        return d
      }
    }
  }
  return max
}

```

}

  } catch {

TITLE: Evaluating Expressions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet implements the `Eval` instruction.  It pops the top address from the stack, saves the current instruction sequence and stack into the dump, clears the stack and pushes the saved address, and replaces the current instruction sequence with `Unwind`. This forces the computation of the expression at the given address to Weak Head Normal Form (WHNF).
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
Eval,

    Eval => {
      let addr = state.stack.last()
      let new_stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)
      let dump_item = (state.instructions, new_stack)
      let new_dump = list::push(state.dump, dump_item)
      {
        state with
        instructions = list::singleton(Instruction::Unwind),
        stack = list::singleton(addr),
        dump = new_dump
      }
    }
```

TITLE: Custom Iter Implementation for Bytes in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to implement `Iter` for a custom sequence type, specifically `Bytes` in MoonBit. This example focuses on the structure and highlights the iteration block, which is often similar across different `Iter` implementations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/fundamentals.md#_snippet_70

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
import bytes

fn iter(bytes : Bytes) : Iter[Byte] {
  var i = 0
  fn(yield : (Byte) -> IterResult) : IterResult {
    if i < bytes::length(bytes) {
      let res = yield(bytes[i])
      i = i + 1
      res
    } else {
      IterEnd
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Overloading Addition Operator for Segment Tree Nodes in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines an overloaded `op_add` function for the `Node` type in MoonBit. This function is used to merge two `Node` instances by summing their values.  It acts as the "pushup" operation, maintaining segment sums.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn op_add(n1 : Node, n2 : Node) -> Node {
  match (n1, n2) {
    (Nil, Nil) => Nil
    (Node(i, _, _), Nil) => Node(i, Nil, Nil)
    (Nil, Node(i, _, _)) => Node(i, Nil, Nil)
    (Node(i, _, _), Node(j, _, _)) => Node(i+j, Nil, Nil)
  }
}

```

TITLE: Compiling Let Expressions in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet shows how to compile 'let' expressions. It compiles the expressions corresponding to local variables using `compileC`, then iterates over the variable definitions, compiling and updating offsets. Finally, it compiles the main expression using the passed `comp` function and adds the `Slide` instruction to clean up the unused addresses.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn compile_let(defs : List[(String, Core)], body : Core, comp : Fn(Core, Env) -> List[Instruction], env : Env) -> List[Instruction] {
  let def_compiles = list::map(defs, (def) => compileC(def._2, env))
  let body_compile = comp(body, env)
  let slide_instr = list::singleton(Instruction::Slide(list::length(defs)))
  list::append(list::append(list::concat(def_compiles), body_compile), slide_instr)
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Multiple Bindings of 'a' in Pattern (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code demonstrates the E4081 error. The identifier 'a' is bound twice within the pattern `(Some(a), Some(a))` of the `match` expression. This is invalid because 'a' cannot simultaneously represent potentially different values from both `Some(a)` patterns.  The code attempts to match two optional integers and print their values if both are present.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4081.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f(a : Int?, b : Int?) -> Unit {
  match (a, b) {
    (Some(a), Some(a)) => println("Some({a})")
    //    ^ Error: The identifier a is bound more than once in the same pattern.
    _ => println("None")
  }
}
```

TITLE: MoonBit Fibonacci Function (b.mbt)
DESCRIPTION: Defines a public function `fib2` that calculates the nth Fibonacci number using tail-call optimization.  This function is also part of the `fib` package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/toolchain/moon/tutorial.md#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn fib2(num : Int) -> Int {
  fn aux(n, acc1, acc2) {
    match n {
      0 => acc1
      1 => acc2
      _ => aux(n - 1, acc2, acc1 + acc2)
    }
  }

  aux(num, 0, 1)
}
```

TITLE: Implementing midpoint function in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: This code provides the implementation of the `midpoint` function in Moonbit, which finds the middle snake within a given `Box`. It performs alternating forward and backward searches, storing the results in arrays. The function checks for overlap between the forward and backward searches to identify the middle snake. If the box has size 0, it returns `None`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff3.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn midpoint(box: Box, a: Array[String], b: Array[String]) -> Option[Snake] {
  let x0 = box.x0
  let y0 = box.y0
  let x1 = box.x1
  let y1 = box.y1

  let w = x1 - x0
  let h = y1 - y0

  if w == 0 || h == 0 {
    return None
  }

  let delta = w - h
  let half = (w + h + 1) / 2

  let forward = init[Int](w + h + 3, x0 - 1)
  let backward = init[Int](w + h + 3, x1 + 1)

  backward[half - delta - 1] = x1

  for d in range(0, half + 1) {
    match search(d, forward, a, b, box, true) {
      Some(snake) => {
        return Some(snake)
      }
      None => {}
    }
    match search(d, backward, a, b, box, false) {
      Some(snake) => {
        return Some(snake)
      }
      None => {}
    }
  }
  None
}

```

TITLE: Demonstrating Unnecessary `catch!` Usage in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the E0026 error in MoonBit, where `catch!` is used unnecessarily. The `f()` function raises error `E`, and the `try...catch!` block in `g()` catches it. The compiler already knows that only `E` can be raised, making `catch!` redundant.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0026.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type! E

fn f() -> Unit!E {
  raise E
}

fn g() -> Unit! {
  try {
    f!()
  } catch! {
    E => raise E
  }
}

fn main {
  try {
    g!()
  } catch {
    _ => println("Error")
  }
}
```

TITLE: MoonBit: PushInt Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `PushInt` instruction. It allocates a new `NNum` node on the heap with the specified integer value, and then pushes the address of this newly created node onto the stack. This instruction effectively loads an integer constant onto the stack.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn push_int(s : GState, i : Int) -> GState {
    let addr = new_addr(s.heap)
    let new_heap = { nodes = array_set(s.heap.nodes, addr, { num = i }) }
    { s with heap = new_heap, stack = cons(addr, s.stack) }
  }
```

TITLE: MoonBit: PushArg Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `PushArg` instruction. It retrieves the address of an argument from the stack based on the specified `offset`. It assumes that the stack contains a sequence of addresses where the first address is the super combinator and subsequent addresses are the arguments. It pushes the address of the argument at the given offset onto the stack.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn push_arg(s : GState, offset : Int) -> GState {
    match list_nth(s.stack, offset + 1) {
      Some(addr) => { { s with stack = cons(addr, s.stack) } }
      None => { abort("Arg not found") }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: Compile Binary Operations
DESCRIPTION: This snippet compiles binary operations by looking up the corresponding instruction in the `builtinOpS` hash table. It compiles the two operands using `compileC`, then retrieves the appropriate instruction and appends it to the instruction list.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
| App(op, [e1, e2]) =>
  match builtinOpS.get(op) with
    | Some instr => compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [instr]
    | None => compileC (App(op, [e1, e2])) ++ [Eval]
```

TITLE: Modify Unwind Instruction for NGlobal
DESCRIPTION: This snippet modifies the `Unwind` instruction's behavior for the `NGlobal` branch. When the number of arguments is insufficient and the dump contains saved stacks, it retains the original redex and restores the stack, ensuring correct handling of partial applications. This change is crucial for the context-based compilation strategy to work correctly with higher-order functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
| NGlobal sym num_args =>
  if args.length < num_args && not dump.is_empty() then
    let (stack_top, new_dump) = dump.pop()
    {
      stack: stack_top,
      dump: new_dump,
      globals: globals,
      code: [Unwind],
      arg_stack: arg_stack
    }
  else
    let global_code = globals[sym].code
    {
      stack: args,
      dump: dump,
      globals: globals,
      code: global_code,
      arg_stack: arg_stack
    }
```

TITLE: Coordinate Conversion to Integer Index in Rust
DESCRIPTION: This Rust function converts a Sudoku grid coordinate (e.g., "A1") to an integer index (0-80). It checks if the input string is a valid coordinate and then calculates the index based on the row and column.  The function also uses a helper function `in` to validate if the characters are within the expected ranges. It will `abort` if an invalid coordinate is given.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
// A1 => 0, A2 => 1
fn square_to_int(s : String) -> Int {
  if in(s[0], 'A', 'I') && in(s[1], '1', '9') {
    let row = s[0].to_int() - 65 // 'A' <=> 0
    let col = s[1].to_int() - 49 // '1' <=> 0
    return row * 9 + col
  } else {
    abort("square_to_int(): \{s} is not a square")
  }
}

// Helper function `in` checks if a character is between `lw` and `up`
fn in(this : Char, lw : Char, up : Char) -> Bool {
  this >= lw && this <= up
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit Code: Incorrect Attribute Usage
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code demonstrates the E4121 error.  The error occurs because the `!`, `?`, and `!!` attributes are incorrectly used on the `IntErr` constructor and the `square` function, which does not raise errors. The attributes are removed in the suggestion section.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4121.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
enum Err {
  IntErr(Int)
}

fn square(x: Int) -> Int {
  x * x
}

fn main {
  IntErr!(1) |> ignore() // Error: The attribute `!` cannot be used on constructors.
  IntErr?(2) |> ignore() // Error: The attribute `?` cannot be used on constructors.
  IntErr!!(3) |> ignore() // Error: The attribute `!!` cannot be used on constructors.
  square!(1) |> ignore() // Error: The attribute `!` cannot be used on application that does not raise errors
  square?(2) |> ignore() // Error: The attribute `?` cannot be used on application that does not raise errors
}
```

TITLE: E_Constr_Case Compilation Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code defines the compilation logic for `case` expressions involving constructors (`E_Constr_Case`) within the `compileE` function. It handles pattern matching on data constructors. Since the object matched by the `case` expression needs to be evaluated to WHNF, it is compiled within `compileE`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
/* start e_constr_case definition */
  | E_Constr_Case(e, cases) => {
    val addr = fresh();
    val labels = cases.map(c => fresh_label());
    acc.push(Grab addr);
    compileE(e, env, acc);
    acc.push(CaseJump labels);
    cases.zip(labels).iter((c, label) => {
      acc.push(LabelDef label);
      match c {
        (pattern, body) => {
          // pattern: (Constr, List[Bind])
          match pattern {
            (Constr(name, binders), exp) => {
              if (binders.length != 0) {
                acc.push(Split { fail : fresh_label() });
                binders.iteri((i, name) => {
                  acc.push(GrabOffset { offset : i, addr : env.get(name).get() });
                });
                compileE(exp, env, acc);
              } else {
                compileE(exp, env, acc);
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    });
    acc;
  }
  /* end e_constr_case definition */
```

TITLE: Rearranging Stack for Supercombinator Parameters in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet defines the `rearrange` function which adjusts the stack before calling a supercombinator.  It takes the top N addresses on the stack, assuming they point to NApp nodes, keeps the bottommost one for Redex update, cleans up the top N-1 addresses, and places N addresses pointing directly to the parameters. This allows accessing parameters and local variables in a consistent way.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn rearrange(state: GState, n: Int) -> GState {
  let addr = state.stack.last()
  let new_stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)
  let new_stack = list::drop(new_stack, n - 1)
  let new_stack = list::push(new_stack, addr)
  let new_stack = list::append(new_stack, list::take(state.stack, n))
  { state with stack = new_stack }
}
```

  "targets": {
    "only_js.mbt": ["js"],
    "only_wasm.mbt": ["wasm"],

    "all_wasm.mbt": ["wasm", "wasm-gc"],

TITLE: Erroneous Loop Label Declaration in MoonBit

    [] => break
    _ => continue read~ read()
    //            ^~~~~

  }

}

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Conflicting Trait Implementations in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4062 error. It defines a trait `T`, a type `A`, and then provides both an implicit implementation (`A::f`) and an explicit `impl` block that redefines `f` for type `A`. This shadowing causes inconsistent behavior depending on where the trait is accessed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4062.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit

  f(Self) -> Int
}

pub type A Int

pub fn A::f(self : A) -> Int {
  println("A::f")
  self._
}

impl T for A with f(self : A) -> Int {
  //              ^
  // Error: This `impl` shadows method f of A previously defined at ...
  //        This will result in different implementations for T inside and outside current package.
  println("impl T for A with f")
  self._
}
```

TITLE: Backtracking Second Part in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code shows the second part of backtracking implementation. It includes array deduplication and reversing the edit sequence
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff2.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  // delete duplicated adjacent Delete/Insert edit
  fn remove_dup[T: Eq](edits: List[Edit[T]]) -> List[Edit[T]] {
    match edits {
      Nil => edits,
      Cons(head, tail) => {
        match head {
          Insert(e1) => match tail {
            Cons(Insert(e2), _) => remove_dup(Cons(Keep(e1), Cons(Insert(e2), tail.tail()))),
            _ => Cons(head, remove_dup(tail)),
          },
          Delete(e1) => match tail {
            Cons(Delete(e2), _) => remove_dup(Cons(Keep(e1), Cons(Delete(e2), tail.tail()))),
            _ => Cons(head, remove_dup(tail)),
          },
          _ => Cons(head, remove_dup(tail)),
        }
      }
    }
  }

  // reverse edit order
  fn reverse[T](edits: List[T]) -> List[T] {
    var result: List[T] = List::new()
    var current = edits
    while !current.is_empty() {
      match current {
        Cons(head, tail) => {
          result = Cons(head, result)
          current = tail
        }
        Nil => {}
      }
    }
    result
  }
```

TITLE: Shortest Edit Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the definition of the `shortest_edit` function in MoonBit, responsible for calculating the shortest edit distance between two sequences by searching a graph.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff2.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn shortest_edit[T: Eq](xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> Int {
  let max_len = xs.length() + ys.length()
  let v = Array::make(2 * max_len + 1, 0)
  let delta = xs.length() - ys.length()
  let max_d = xs.length() + ys.length()

  // Function to check if the path reaches the end
  fn reach_end(x: Int, y: Int, xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> Bool {
    x == xs.length() && y == ys.length()
  }

  // Function to perform a free move
  fn free_move(x: Int, y: Int, xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> (Int, Int) {
    var x = x
    var y = y
    while x < xs.length() && y < ys.length() && xs[x] == ys[y] {
      x += 1
      y += 1
    }
    (x, y)
  }

  for d in 0..=max_d {
    for k in -d..=d by 2 {
      let x = if k == -d || (k != d && v[max_len + k - 1] < v[max_len + k + 1]) {
        v[max_len + k + 1]
      } else {
        v[max_len + k - 1] + 1
      }
      let y = x - k

      let (x, y) = free_move(x, y, xs, ys)
      v[max_len + k] = x
      if reach_end(x, y, xs, ys) {
        return d
      }
    }
  }
  max_d
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Unresolved Type Variables
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the E0013 error in MoonBit with local functions and empty collections lacking explicit type annotations. The compiler defaults unresolved type variables to `Unit`, which can lead to unexpected behavior.

pub fn f1() -> Unit {
  fn f(x) {
//     ^ Warning: The type of this expression is Option[_/0], which contains
//                unresolved type variables. The type variable is default to
//                Unit.
    match x {
      None => ()
      Some(a) => println(a)
    }
  }

  f(None)
}

pub fn f2() -> Unit {
  fn f(x : Array[_]) -> Int {
//     ^ Warning: The type of this expression is Array[_/0], which contains
//                unresolved type variables. The type variable is default to
//                Unit.
    x.length()
  }

  println(f([]))
}

fn main {
  let a = []
//        ^^ Warning: The type of this expression is Array[_/0], which contains
//           unresolved type variables. The type variable is default to Unit.
  println(a.length())
  let b = None
//        ^^ Warning: The type of this expression is Option[_/0], which contains
//           unresolved type variables. The type variable is default to Unit.
  println(b.is_empty())
}

```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit Loop Pattern
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the E4103 error.  The loop takes two arguments (x and y), but the second arm only provides one pattern (a). This mismatch between the number of arguments and patterns triggers the error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4103.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int, y: Int) -> Int {
  loop x, y {
    0, 0 => 0
    a => continue a - 1, 0
//  ^ Error: This loop has 2 arguments, but 1 patterns are supplied
  }
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Accessing Non-Existent Field
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the E4113 error in MoonBit. The code defines an enum `E` with a constructor `A` containing a field `a`. It then attempts to access a non-existent field `b` on an instance of `A`, triggering the error. Requires the MoonBit compiler to reproduce.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4113.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub enum E {
  A(a~: Int)
}

pub fn f(x: E) -> Unit {
  match x {
    A(..) as a => {
      println(a.a)
      println(a.b)
//            ^^^ Error: Constructor A of type E has no field b.
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Sudoku Grid Constants in Rust
DESCRIPTION: These Rust constants define the rows, columns, and squares of a Sudoku grid. The `squares`, `units`, and `peers` constants are used to represent the structure of the Sudoku grid and are necessary for the solving algorithm. The `units` constant is a `SquareMap` that maps a square to a list of other squares in the same unit. The `peers` constant is a `SquareMap` that maps a square to a list of its peers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
let rows = "ABCDEFGHI"
let cols = "123456789"

// squares contains the coordinates of each square
let squares : List[String] = ......

// units[coord] contains the other squares in the unit of the square at coord
// for exampleunits["A3"] => [C3, C2, C1, B3, B2, B1, A2, A1]
let units : SquareMap[List[String]] = ......

// peers[coord] contains all the peers of the square at coord
// for examplepeers["A3"] => [A1, A2, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9, B1, B2, B3, C1, C2, C3, D3, E3, F3, G3, H3, I3]
let peers : SquareMap[List[String]] = ......
```

TITLE: Testing Qualified Students in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates a black box test for the `examine` package, specifically testing the `count_qualified_students` function. It defines an array of `Student` records with `id` and `score` fields, and uses two different criteria to count qualified students. Type annotations are included to specify the types of the `students` variable.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/tutorial/tour.md#_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
:class: top-level
test "count qualified students" {
  let students: Array[@examine.Student] = [
    { id: "0", score: 10.0 },
    { id: "1", score: 50.0 },
    { id: "2", score: 61.0 },
  ]
  let criteria1 = fn(student) { @examine.is_qualified(student, 10) }
  let criteria2 = fn(student) { @examine.is_qualified(student, 50) }
  assert_eq!(@examine.count_qualified_students(students, criteria1), 3)
  assert_eq!(@examine.count_qualified_students(students, criteria2), 2)
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Conditional Branching in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the Cond instruction, which performs conditional branching based on the value on the top of the stack. If the value is 0 (false), it executes the 'else' branch; otherwise (true), it executes the 'then' branch. The instructions for the chosen branch replace the current instruction sequence.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
Cond(then_branch: List[Instruction], else_branch: List[Instruction]),

    Cond(then_branch, else_branch) => {
      let addr = state.stack.last()
      match state.heap[addr] {
        Node::NNum(0) => {
          {state with instructions = else_branch, stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)}
        }
        _ => {
          {state with instructions = then_branch, stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)}
        }
      }
    }
```

TITLE: Simplified x Coordinate Calculation in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This is a simplified version of the previous code. This logic combines the previous four branches into one. It calculates the x coordinate based on k and previous coordinate values from v array
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff.md#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
if k == -d || (k != d && v[k - 1] < v[k + 1]) {
  x = v[k + 1]
} else {

}

}

TITLE: Converting Term to TermDBI with Helper Function in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code defines the core conversion logic from `Term` to `TermDBI` in MoonBit.  It uses a helper function `go` that recursively traverses the Lambda term, maintaining a list of variable names and their corresponding depths. The function handles `Var`, `Abs`, and `App` cases, updating the index list and generating the appropriate `TermDBI` representation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/lambda/index.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn bruijn(self : Term) -> Result[TermDBI, String] {
  struct Ctx {
    index : @immut/list.T[Index]
  }

  fn go(index : @immut/list.T[Index], term : Term) -> Result[TermDBI, String] {
    match term {
      Var(varname) => {
        match find_depth(varname, index) {
          Ok(depth) => Ok(VarDBI(depth, varname))
          Err(err) => Err(err)
        }
      }
      Abs(varname, body) => {
        let new_index = Cons(Index { name : varname, depth : 0 }, index.map(fn (x) { Index { name : x.name, depth : x.depth + 1 } }))
        match go(new_index, body) {
          Ok(body_dbi) => Ok(AbsDBI(varname, body_dbi))
          Err(err) => Err(err)
        }
      }
      App(t1, t2) => {
        match (go(index, t1), go(index, t2)) {
          (Ok(t1_dbi), Ok(t2_dbi)) => Ok(AppDBI(t1_dbi, t2_dbi))
          (Err(err), _) => Err(err)
          (_, Err(err)) => Err(err)
        }
      }
    }
  }

```

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```

TITLE: Pretty Printing Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code defines the `pprint` function in MoonBit for printing the diff in a human-readable format, aligning text and presenting insertions, deletions, and unchanged lines clearly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff2.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn pprint[T: ToString](edits: List[Edit[T]]) -> Effect[Unit] {
  for (i, edit) in edits.iter().enumerate() {
    match edit {
      Insert(t) => println("+\t\t{t}"),
      Delete(t) => println("-\t\t{t}"),
      Keep(t) => println(" \t{i}\t{t}"),
    }
  }
}
```
