TITLE: MoonBit: Unwind Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `Unwind` instruction, which is the core evaluation loop of the G-Machine. It checks the node type at the top of the stack and performs different actions based on the type. It handles `NNum`, `NApp`, `NGlobal`, and `NInd` nodes, recursively unwinding the stack until a normal form or a global function with enough arguments is found.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_20

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn unwind(s : GState) -> GState {
    match s.stack {
      Nil => { abort("Stack underflow") }
      Cons(addr, _) => {
        match array_get(s.heap.nodes, addr) {
          { num } => { s }
          { app } => {
            // Push the left node and unwind again
            let (fun_addr, _) = app
            { s with stack = cons(fun_addr, s.stack) }
          }
          { global } => {
            // Check if there are enough parameters on the stack
            // Load this super combinator into the current code
            s
          }
          { ind } => {
            // Push the address contained within this indirect node onto the stack and Unwind again.
            { s with stack = cons(ind, s.stack) }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: Implementing Queries with Lazy Propagation in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the query function. The query function pushes the LazyTag downwards to ensure correct results when querying ranges. It applies the lazy tag to the children before making the recursive calls.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree2.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn query[Data: Op_add[Data, Tag] + Op_add_tag[Data, Tag], Tag: Op_add_tag[Data, Tag]](node: Node[Data, Tag], l: Int, r: Int, ql: Int, qr: Int) -> Data {
  if ql <= l && qr >= r {
    match node {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { data, .. } => data
    }
  } else if qr < l || ql > r {
    // Return a neutral element that doesn't affect the sum
    // This depends on the specific Data type and operation
    // For example, if Data is Int and the operation is addition, return 0
    // If Data is Int and the operation is multiplication, return 1
    // Here, we assume Data has a zero() function to return a neutral element
    zero()
  } else {
    match node {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { left, right, data, tag, len } => {
        let left = apply(left, tag)
        let right = apply(right, tag)

        let mid = l + (r - l) / 2
        let left_result = query(left, l, mid, ql, qr)
        let right_result = query(right, mid + 1, r, ql, qr)
        op_add(left_result, right_result)
      }
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Solution 1: Adding a Continue Statement (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to resolve the E0018 error by adding a `continue` statement within the `loop` expression.  The `countdown` function now includes a `continue` statement to restart the loop after decrementing the counter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0018.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn countdown(n : Int) -> Int {
  let mut count = n
  loop count {
    _..<0 => break
    _ => {
      continue count - 1
    }
  }
  return count
}
```

TITLE: MoonBit: PushGlobal Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `PushGlobal` instruction. It retrieves the address of the global super combinator (identified by its name) from the global table and pushes that address onto the stack. It assumes the global table contains the mapping between names and heap addresses of the combinators.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn push_global(s : GState, name : String) -> GState {
    match get(s.globals, name) {
      Some(addr) => { { s with stack = cons(addr, s.stack) } }
      None => { abort("Global not found") }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: MoonBit: Implement count_qualified_students with for loop
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the `count_qualified_students` function using a mutable counter and a `for` loop in MoonBit. It iterates through the array of students, checks if each student is qualified based on the provided `is_qualified` function, and increments the counter if they are. Finally, it returns the total count of qualified students.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/tutorial/tour.md#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn count_qualified_students(
  students : Array[Student],
  is_qualified : (Student) -> ExamResult
) -> Int {
  let mut count = 0
  for i = 0; i < students.length(); i = i + 1 {
    if is_qualified(students[i]) == Pass {
      count += 1
    }
  }
  count
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the MoonBit compiler error E4134. The anonymous function `fn(luck : Int) -> Int` is expected to return an error type (`Int!`) because it uses `fail!`. However, the return type annotation is missing the error type. This causes the compiler to raise error E4134.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4134.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  let draw : (Int) -> Int! = fn(luck : Int) -> Int {
    //                                         ^~~
    // Error: The return type of this anonymous function is expected include an
    // error type. Please add the error type to the return type annotation or
    // use `fn!` instead.
    if luck == 7 {
      return 42
    }
    fail!("Bad luck") // E4122 as well
  }
  try {
    println("Draw: \{draw!(7)}")
  } catch {
    error => println("Error: \{error}")
  }
}
```

TITLE: MoonBit: Update Instruction Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `Update` instruction. It updates a node in the heap with an indirection (`NInd`) to the result of the computation. The offset specifies which node to update based on the stack layout.  If updating a CAF (constant applicative form), it updates the `NGlobal` node directly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
  fn update(s : GState, offset : Int) -> GState {
    match s.stack {
      Nil => { abort("Stack underflow") }
      Cons(result_addr, rest) => {
        match list_nth(s.stack, offset + 1) {
          Some(update_addr) => {
            let new_heap = { nodes = array_set(s.heap.nodes, update_addr, { ind = result_addr }) }
            { s with heap = new_heap }
          }
          None => { abort("Update address not found") }
        }
      }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: SquareMap Data Structure Implementation in Rust
DESCRIPTION: This Rust code implements a `SquareMap` data structure for storing Sudoku grid values, using an array as the underlying storage. It provides methods for creating a `SquareMap`, copying it, and accessing/setting values using the `op_get` and `op_set` methods, which enable convenient syntax like `table["A2"]`.  This struct represents the 9x9 Sudoku grid.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
struct SquareMap[T] {
  contents : Array[T]
}

fn SquareMap::new[T](val : T) -> SquareMap[T] {
  { contents : Array::make(81, val) }
}

fn copy[T](self : SquareMap[T]) -> SquareMap[T] {
  let arr = Array::make(81, self.contents[0])
  let mut i = 0
  while i < 81 {
    arr[i] = self.contents[i]
    i = i + 1
  }
  return { contents : arr }
}

fn op_get[T](self : SquareMap[T], square : String) -> T {
  self.contents[square_to_int(square)]
}

fn op_set[T](self : SquareMap[T], square : String, x : T) -> Unit {
  self.contents[square_to_int(square)] = x
}
```

TITLE: Async Primitive Example in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code provides an example of how the `%async.suspend` and `%async.run` primitives work together. `suspend` captures the current coroutine's continuation and passes it to a callback for resuming or throwing an error. This enables coroutine cancellation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/async-experimental.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn async_worker(i: Int) -> Int:
  builtin %println(debug_show("async_worker " + debug_show(i)))
  let result = %async.suspend[Int]((cb: Result[fn(Int), fn(Error)]) => {
    builtin %println(debug_show("suspend " + debug_show(i)))
    match cb {
      Ok(resume_ok) => {
        builtin %println(debug_show("resume_ok " + debug_show(i)))
        resume_ok(i + 1)
      }
      Err(resume_err) => {
        builtin %println(debug_show("resume_err " + debug_show(i)))
        resume_err(Error::new("resume_err"))
      }
    }
  })
  builtin %println(debug_show("after suspend " + debug_show(i)))
  result

fn run_async() -> Result[Int, Error]:
  %async.run(() => {
    let result = async_worker(1)
    builtin %println(debug_show("result: " + debug_show(result)))
  })

```

TITLE: G-Machine Initial Code Definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code defines the initial code for the G-Machine. This sets up the initial state of the machine, including the code to be executed.  Changing the initial code allows for the execution of programs that utilize lazy lists and custom data structures.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
/* start init definition */
let init_code = {
  let fibs = E_App(E_App(E_Var(`Cons`), E_Num(0)), E_App(E_App(E_Var(`Cons`), E_Num(1)), E_App(E_App(E_App(E_Var(`zipWith`), E_Var(`add`)), E_Var(`fibs`)), E_App(E_Var(`tail`), E_Var(`fibs`)))))
  compileE(fibs, [], []).push(GPrint).push(Halt)
}

{
  code : init_code,
  stack : [],
  heap : [],
  globals : [
    (`add`, builtin_add_addr),
    (`zipWith`, builtin_zipWith_addr),
    (`tail`, builtin_tail_addr),
    (`Cons`, builtin_cons_addr),
    (`Nil`, builtin_nil_addr)
  ],
  output : [],
}/* end init definition */
```

TITLE: Erroneous Method Definition for Built-in Type (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows the E4059 error occurring when a method `f` is defined directly on the built-in type `Int`. MoonBit does not allow extending built-in types with new methods.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4059.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:

TITLE: MoonBit: Implement count_qualified_students with for..in loop
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the `count_qualified_students` function in MoonBit using a `for .. in` loop for iterating over the array of students. It checks each student's qualification using the provided `is_qualified` function and increments the counter if the student has passed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/tutorial/tour.md#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn count_qualified_students(
  students : Array[Student],
  is_qualified : (Student) -> ExamResult
) -> Int {
  let mut count = 0
  for student in students {
    if is_qualified(student) == Pass { count += 1}
  }
  count
}
```

TITLE: Implementing search function in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet presents the implementation of the `search` function in Moonbit. This function performs either a forward or backward search within a given `Box` to find a Snake. It calculates the previous coordinate (`px`) and converts between global and local coordinates. The backward search minimizes `y` as a heuristic, although minimizing `x` would also work.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff3.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn search(d: Int, v: Array[Int], a: Array[String], b: Array[String], box: Box, forward: Bool) -> Option[Snake] {
  let x0 = box.x0
  let y0 = box.y0
  let x1 = box.x1
  let y1 = box.y1
  let w = x1 - x0
  let h = y1 - y0

  let delta = w - h

  if forward {
    for k in range(-d, d + 1, 2) {
      let real_k = k + w - h
      let prev_k = real_k - 1
      let next_k = real_k + 1

      let px = if k == -d || v[prev_k] < v[next_k] {
        v[next_k]
      } else {
        v[prev_k] + 1
      }

      let py = px - k
      let mut x = px
      let mut y = py

      while x < x1 && y < y1 && x >= x0 && y >= y0 && a[x] == b[y] {
        x = x + 1
        y = y + 1
      }

      v[real_k] = x
      if delta % 2 != 0 && delta - d <= k && k <= delta + d && x > v[k + w - h] {
        return Some(Snake { x: x, y: y, px: px, py: py })
      }
    }
  } else {
    for c in range(-d, d + 1, 2) {
      let real_c = c + d
      let prev_c = real_c - 1
      let next_c = real_c + 1

      let px = if c == d || v[prev_c] < v[next_c] {
        v[prev_c]
      } else {
        v[next_c] + 1
      }

      let py = px - (delta + c)
      let mut x = px
      let mut y = py

      while x > x0 && y > y0 && x <= x1 && y <= y1 && a[x - 1] == b[y - 1] {
        x = x - 1
        y = y - 1
      }

      v[real_c] = x

      if delta % 2 == 0 && -d - delta <= c && c <= d - delta && x < v[c + d] {
        return Some(Snake { x: x, y: y, px: px, py: py })
      }
    }
  }
  None
}

```

TITLE: Inconsistent Size Trait Implementations for Array in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the E4135 error in Moonbit. It attempts to implement the `Size` trait for `Array[T]` twice, once with the constraint `T : ByteSize` and once with the constraint `T : WordSize`. This results in an error because the implementations have different constraints. The error message highlights the conflicting implementations at specific lines.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4135.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
impl[T : ByteSize] Size for Array[T] with size(self) {
  self.length() * T::byte_size()
}

impl[T : WordSize] Size for Array[T] with size(self) {
//<~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// Error: Inconsistent `impl` of trait Size for Array at 11:1 and 15:1:
//   type parameters of implementations have different constraints
  self.length() * T::word_size() * 4
}
```

TITLE: Split and Pack instructions definition in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code defines the `Split` and `Pack` virtual machine instructions for deconstructing and constructing lists. These instructions are essential for handling custom data structures like lazy lists in the G-Machine.  The `Split` instruction is used to deconstruct a list into its head and tail, while the `Pack` instruction is used to construct a new list from a head and a tail.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
/* start split_pack definition */
  | Split {
    // sp -> addr of list (nconstr)
    // if head is Nil, jump to the label
    // otherwise,
    //   move head node addr to sp + 0
    //   move tail node addr to sp + 1
    //   continue
    fail : Label, 
  }
  | Pack {
    // sp+0: head node addr
    // sp+1: tail node addr
    // addr <- Cons head tail
    // sp -> addr
  }
  /* end split_pack definition */
```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit For-Loop Example
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the E4106 error in MoonBit. The variable `j` is used in the update expression of the for-loop but is not declared in the initialization block, leading to the error. The function `f` takes an integer `x` and attempts to print `i` and `j` within the loop.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4106.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int) -> Unit {
  let mut j = 0
  for i = 0; i < x; i = i + 1, j = j + 1 {
//                             ^ --- Error: Unknown binder j in the for-loop
//                                          steps. Binders in the steps must be
//                                          declared in the initialization
//                                          block of the for-loop.
    println(i)
    println(j)
  }
}
```

TITLE: Loop Label Shadowing Example in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the E0036 warning in MoonBit where a loop label `l` is reused in a nested loop, shadowing the outer label. This can lead to confusion when using `break` or `continue` statements. The suggestion is to use distinct, descriptive label names.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0036.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f(xss : Array[Array[Int]]) -> Unit {
  l~: for xs in xss {
    l~: for x in xs {
//  ^^  Warning: The label name `l` shadows a label name that is already in
//               scope.
      if x > 0 {
        break l~
      }
    }
  }
}
```

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
    f2!()
  } catch! {

}
```

```
    div!(x, y)
  } catch { // `catch` and `except` works the same.

  } else {
    v => println(v)
  }
}
```

TITLE: Deprecated Method Call Example (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the deprecated method call style in MoonBit that triggers the E0040 error. It defines a type `A` and a method `A::f`. The `main` function then attempts to call `f` directly, resulting in a deprecation warning.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0040.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type A Int

fn A::f(self : A) -> Int {
  self._
}

fn main {
  let _ = f(A(1))
  // Warning:
  // This method is declared as A::f, calling this kind of method directly via
  // f(..) is deprecated, use qualified syntax A::f(..), or declare the method
  // as `fn f(self : A, ..)` instead.
}
```

TITLE: Invalid Self Type in Trait Implementation (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the E4053 error when attempting to implement a trait for a type parameter 'X' using 'self' of type 'X', which is not a type constructor. Includes examples with and without constraints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4053.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub trait A {
  f(Self) -> Int
}

// Without constraints
impl[X] A for X with f(self : X) -> Int { // Error: Invalid type for "self": must be a type constructor.
  ignore(self)
  0
}

// With constraints
impl[X: Default] A for X with f(self : X) -> Int { // Error: Invalid type for "self": must be a type constructor.
  ignore(self)
  0
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit code using '?.' together
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4125 error, showing the incorrect usage of the '?' operator after a method chained with '..'.  The '..' operator expects a method returning `Unit`, while `?` converts the result to `Result[T, E]`, leading to a type mismatch. The code defines a struct `A` with methods `check` and `div`. The `main` function attempts to print the result of `a.div(b)..check?()`, which triggers the error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4125.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type A Double derive(Show)

pub fn A::check(self : A) -> Unit! {
  if self._.is_nan() {
    fail!("NaN")
  }
}

pub fn A::div(self : A, other : A) -> A {
  A(self._ / other._)
}

fn main {
  let a : A = 1.0
  let b : A = 2.0
  println(a.div(b)..check?())
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet demonstrates how to configure the `cc-flags` option for the native backend in the `link` section of a `moon.pkg.json` file. It defines a macro called `MOONBIT` that will be passed to the compiler.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/toolchain/moon/package.md#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: JSON
CODE:
```
{
    "link": {
      "native": {
        "cc-flags": "-DMOONBIT"
      }
    }
  }
```

TITLE: Fix: Move Function to Toplevel (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the solution of moving the function `h` that uses labelled arguments to the top level of the module. By defining `h` outside of any other function, it becomes a toplevel function, and the labelled argument `x~` is allowed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4114.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn h(x~: Int) -> Unit {
  println(x)
}

pub fn f() -> Unit {
  h(x=42)
}
```

TITLE: Suggestion: Discarding the First Binding with '_' (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code demonstrates shadowing by explicitly discarding the first binding using `_`. The first `Some`'s value is ignored, and only the second `Some(a)`'s value is bound to the identifier 'a'. This effectively shadows any previous binding of 'a' in the pattern.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4081.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f(a : Int?, b : Int?) -> Unit {
  match (a, b) {
    (Some(_), Some(a)) => println("Some({a})")
    _ => println("None")
  }
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit Pattern Match with `..` Placement
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the E3007 error in MoonBit, which occurs when `..` is not placed at the end of the pattern in a struct destructuring. The code attempts to destructure a struct `S` but incorrectly places `..` between `a` and `c`, leading to a compilation error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E3007.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct S {
  a : Int
  b : Int
  c : Int
}

fn main {
  let s : S = { a : 1, b : 2, c : 3 }
  let { a, .., c } = s
  //       ^^
  // Error: Unexpected `..` here, add `, ..` behind the last field to ignore the rest of record.
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous implementation of trait B for type A - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code attempts to implement the trait `@a.B` for type `@a.A` within package 'b'.  This violates the orphan rule since both the trait and the type are defined in a different package ('a'). The code will result in a compilation error, as indicated in the comment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4061.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
impl @a.B for @a.A with to_int(self : @a.A) -> Int {
  //                    ^~~~~~
  // Error: Cannot define method to_int of trait @a.B from package a for type @a.A from package a
  self._
}
```

TITLE: Incorrect MoonBit 'for in' Loop
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4133 error in MoonBit, where a 'for in' loop uses three loop variables. MoonBit only supports one or two loop variables in 'for in' loops.  The code attempts to iterate over an array [1, 2, 3] and assign each element to variables a, b, and c, which is not allowed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4133.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn main {
  for a, b, c in [1, 2, 3] { // Error: This `for .. in` loop has 3 loop variables, but at most 2 is expected.
    ...
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using 'until' for Floating-Point Range in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates using the `until` function in MoonBit to construct a range of floating-point numbers.  It creates an iterator `range` from 0.0 up to (but not including) 10.0, and then iterates over this range, printing each value.

TITLE: Erroneous Guard Let Example in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the E0038 error where a `guard let` with an irrefutable pattern renders the guard useless.  The code attempts to conditionally abort based on input, but the `guard let _ = input` always succeeds, preventing the early return.  `input` is expected to be an optional Int (`Int?`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0038.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f(input : Int?) -> Int {
  guard let _ = input else {
    Some(_..<0) => abort("Invalid input")
  }
  3
}

fn main {
  ignore(f(None))
}
```

TITLE: Invalid Self Type in Function Definition (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the E4053 error when defining a function with 'self' as a type parameter or a function type, which are not type constructors.

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn f[T](self : T) -> Int { // Error: Invalid type for "self": must be a type constructor.
  ignore(self)
  0
}

fn g(self : (Int) -> Unit) -> Unit { // Error: Invalid type for "self": must be a type constructor.
  self(0)
}
```

TITLE: Wrapping Function Type in a Struct (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This code provides a solution to the E4131 error by wrapping the function type `(Int) -> Unit` in a new type `FuncWrap`.  A method `call` can then be defined on this new type. This allows for method-like behavior to be associated with function types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4131.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type FuncWrap (Int) -> Unit

pub fn FuncWrap::call(self : FuncWrap) -> Unit {
  (self._)(0)
}
```

TITLE: Backtracking First Part in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code provides the first part of the backtracking logic for reconstructing the edit path in the Myers diff algorithm. It takes the end point and traverses backwards to determine the specific path used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff2.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn backtrack_fst[T: Eq](xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> List[Edit[T]] {
  let max_len = xs.length() + ys.length()
  let v = Array::make(2 * max_len + 1, 0)
  let delta = xs.length() - ys.length()
  let max_d = xs.length() + ys.length()
  let path = List::new()

  // Function to check if the path reaches the start
  fn reach_start(x: Int, y: Int) -> Bool {
    x == 0 && y == 0
  }

  // Function to perform a free move in reverse
  fn free_move_back(x: Int, y: Int, xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> (Int, Int) {
    var x = x
    var y = y
    while x > 0 && y > 0 && xs[x - 1] == ys[y - 1] {
      x -= 1
      y -= 1
    }
    (x, y)
  }

  fn shortest_edit_back[T: Eq](xs: List[T], ys: List[T]) -> (Array[Int],Int) {
    let max_len = xs.length() + ys.length()
    let v = Array::make(2 * max_len + 1, 0)
    let delta = xs.length() - ys.length()
    let max_d = xs.length() + ys.length()
    for d in 0..=max_d {
      for k in -d..=d by 2 {
        let x = if k == -d || (k != d && v[max_len + k - 1] < v[max_len + k + 1]) {
          v[max_len + k + 1]
        } else {
          v[max_len + k - 1] + 1
        }
        let y = x - k

        let (x, y) = free_move(x, y, xs, ys)
        v[max_len + k] = x
        if x == xs.length() && y == ys.length(){
          return (v,d)
        }
      }
    }
    (v,max_d)
  }

  let (v,max_d) = shortest_edit_back(xs,ys)

  var x = xs.length()
  var y = ys.length()
  var d = max_d

  while d >= 0 {
    let k = x - y
    let prev_k:Int = if k == -d || (k != d && v[max_len + k - 1] < v[max_len + k + 1]) {
      k+1
    }else{
      k-1
    }

    let prev_x:Int = if k == -d || (k != d && v[max_len + k - 1] < v[max_len + k + 1]) {
      v[max_len + k + 1]
    }else{
      v[max_len + k - 1] + 1
    }
    let prev_y = prev_x - prev_k

    let (x_back,y_back) = free_move_back(x,y,xs,ys)

    if x_back != x{
      //println("Free Move!")
      x = x_back
      y = y_back
      d -= 1
      continue
    }

    if k > prev_k{
      //println("Delete!")
      path.push_front(Edit::Delete(xs[x-1]))
      x -= 1
      d -= 1
    }else{
      //println("Insert!")
      path.push_front(Edit::Insert(ys[y-1]))
      y -= 1
      d -= 1
    }

    if reach_start(x,y) {
      break
    }
  }
  path
}
```

TITLE: Diff Output - Bad Quality
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates a 'bad quality' diff output, where the insertion of a function is interleaved with the existing struct definition. It highlights the undesirability of such interleaved changes and the need for algorithms that prioritize logical placement of edits.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: diff
CODE:
```
 struct RHSet[T] {
    set : RHTable[T, Unit]
+ }
+
+ fn RHSet::new[T](capacity : Int) -> RHSet[T] {
+  let set : RHTable[T, Unit]= RHTable::new(capacity)
+  { set : set }
  }
```

TITLE: Incorrect Continue Arguments in Loop - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the E4104 error in a MoonBit `loop` where the `continue` statement provides only one argument, but the loop expects two. The error message highlights the mismatch in the number of arguments. The loop takes two integer arguments x and y.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4104.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int, y: Int) -> Int {
  loop x, y {
    0, 0 => 0
    a, _ => continue a - 1
//          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Error: Current loop expects 2 arguments, but
//                                `continue` is supplied with 1 arguments
  }
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the error E4114 by defining a local function `h` within `f` that attempts to use a labelled argument `x~`. The MoonBit compiler will flag this as an error because labelled arguments are only allowed in toplevel functions.

TITLE: Factorial Function in coreF (Clojure-like)
DESCRIPTION: Defines a `factorial` function in the coreF language, resembling Clojure. This function calculates the factorial of a given number `n` using recursion. Note that `eq`, `mul`, and `sub` are built-in functions in coreF.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: clojure
CODE:
```
(defn factorial[n] ;; n is the parameter, this function calculates the factorial of n
  (if (eq n 0) ;; The definition starts here and continues for the next three lines
    1
    (mul n (factorial (sub n 1)))))
```

```
    if i == 42 {

//    ^^^^^ Error: Current loop has result type Int, but `break` is supplied

    }
  } else {

  }
}
```

TITLE: Unused Toplevel Variable Example - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates an example of an unused toplevel variable 'p' in MoonBit, which triggers the E0002 warning. The warning indicates that the variable is not used and any side effects within its definition will not occur.  The suggestion is to use `fn init { .. }` to wrap the effect.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0002.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```

//  ^ Warning: Unused toplevel variable 'p'.
//             Note if the body contains side effect, it will not happen.
//             Use `fn init { .. }` to wrap the effect.
  println("Side effect")
  42
}

fn main {
  let x = 42 // Warning: Unused variable 'x'
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the incorrect usage of multiple intrinsics in a MoonBit function. The `MyArray::get` function attempts to associate both `%array.get` and `%fixedarray.get` intrinsics, leading to an E4071 error. The function aims to retrieve an element from an array-like structure using an index.

```
type MyArray[T] Array[T]

/// @intrinsic %fixedarray.get

  return self._[index]
}
```

TITLE: Labelled Arguments Error Example - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4117 error in MoonBit. The `accumulate` function uses a labelled argument (`acc~`) and is passed to `func_takes_closure`. This is not allowed in MoonBit, resulting in the error message 'Function with labelled arguments can only be applied directly.'
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4117.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```

  ...
}

pub fn accumulate(acc~ : Int, value : Int) -> Int {
  acc + value
}

fn main {
  func_takes_closure(accumulate)
  //                 ^~~~~~~~~~
  // Error: Function with labelled arguments can only be applied directly.
}
```

TITLE: Allocating Indirect Nodes in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code defines the `Alloc(N)` instruction, which pre-allocates N `NInd` (indirect) nodes on the heap and pushes their addresses onto the stack. The addresses in these indirect nodes are initialized to negative values as placeholders. This instruction is used for implementing `letrec` expressions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
Alloc(n: Int),

    Alloc(n) => {
      let addrs = list::make_with_index(n, (i) => state.heap.alloc(Node::NInd(-1)))
      {state with stack = list::append(state.stack, addrs)}
    }
```

TITLE: Default Compile & Link Command for GCC-like Compilers
DESCRIPTION: This shell command represents the default compilation and linking process used for GCC-like compilers within the MoonBit build system.  It defines how source files are compiled and linked to create the target executable. Flags enclosed in square brackets `[]` are optional and may not be present in all modes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/toolchain/moon/package.md#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
cc -o $target -I$MOON_HOME/include -L$MOON_HOME/lib [-g] [-shared -fPIC] \
   -fwrapv -fno-strict-aliasing (-O2|-Og) [$MOON_HOME/lib/libmoonbitrun.o] \
   $sources -lm $cc_flags $cc_link_flags
```

TITLE: Assigning a Single Value and Eliminating Others in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This function assigns a specific value to a square by eliminating all other possible values. It takes a `SquareMap`, a square `key`, and a value `val` to assign. It removes all values from `key` except `val` and returns a boolean indicating success or failure based on constraint propagation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/sudoku/index.md#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
fn assign(values : SquareMap[List[Char]], key : String, val : Char) -> Bool {
  let other_values = values[key].remove(val)
  let mut result = true
  other_values.iter(fn (val) {
    result = result && eliminate(values, key, val)
  })
  return result
}
```

TITLE: Pseudo Code for Free Variable Check in Moonbit (Hypothetical)
DESCRIPTION: This is pseudo code that represents a potential, but ultimately not implemented, approach to handling variable capture. It highlights the complexities of checking for free variables during substitution. The final implementation uses de Bruijn indices to avoid this issue altogether, making the substitution process simpler and more efficient.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/lambda/index.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
// (x.E) T => E.subst(x, T)
fn subst(self : Term, var : String, term : Term) -> Term {
  let freeVars : Set[String] = term.get_free_vars()
  match self {
    Abs(variable, body) => {
      if freeVars.contains(variable) {
        // The variable name is in the set of free variables 
        // of the current inner Lambda, indicating variable capture
        abort("subst(): error while encountering {variable}")
      } else {
        ...
      }
    }
    ...
  }
}
```

TITLE: Incorrect Continue Arguments in For Loop - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This example shows the E4104 error within a MoonBit `for` loop. The `continue` statement is given three arguments (i + 2, j + 1, i + j) while the loop only expects two (i, j). The error message points out this discrepancy, leading to the compilation failure.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4104.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn g(x : Int, y : Int) -> Int {
  for i = x, j = y; i + j < 10; i = i + 1, j = j + 1 {
    if i < j {
      continue i + 2, j + 1, i + j
//    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Error: Current loop expects 2 arguments, but
//                                       `continue` is supplied with 3 arguments
    }
  } else {
    42
  }
}
```

```
  }
```

TITLE: Erroneous MoonBit Trait Implementation
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code demonstrates error E4060, where the method `f` in the `impl` block has a type `(T) -> Unit`, while the trait `A` expects `(T) -> Int`. This mismatch causes the compiler error. The example highlights that the method signatures must be exactly the same.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4060.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait A {
  f(Self) -> Int
}

type T Int

impl A for T with f(self : T) -> Int {
  //              ^
  // Error: Method f of trait A is expected to have type (T) -> Int,
  //        it cannot be implemented with type (T) -> Unit
  ignore(self)
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Duplicate Label in Function Call (Moonbit)
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4084 error. The function `f` is called with the labeled parameter `a` specified twice, which is not allowed.  This results in a compiler error. The function `f` expects a labeled parameter `a~` of type `Int`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4084.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(a~ : Int) -> Unit {
  println("Hello, \{a}")
}

fn main {
  f(a=0, a=1) // Error: The label a~ is supplied twice.
}
```

TITLE: Suggested Solution: Remove Optional Argument (Moonbit)
DESCRIPTION: This Moonbit code snippet presents a solution to the E0031 error by removing the optional argument `opt` from the function `f` and defining it as a local variable within the function. This eliminates the warning and maintains the original functionality.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0031.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```

  let opt = 4
  ignore(opt)
  0
}

fn main {
  println(f())
  println(f())
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code demonstrates how to pass an integer array to JavaScript through FFI when using the WASM linear backend. It defines an external type `JsArray` and functions to create and push elements to a JavaScript array. The `make_js_array` and `push_js_array` functions are FFI functions that interact with JavaScript host functions.

TITLE: Erroneous Range Pattern Example - MoonBit

SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E3018.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
  }
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code snippet demonstrates an error where the overloaded `op_add` operator for type `A` has an inconsistent parameter type. It expects the second argument to be of type `A`, but the provided code uses `Int` instead.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4066.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
type A Int
fn A::op_add(self : A, other : Int) -> A {
  return self._ + other
```

TITLE: Convert List to Stream in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Converts a regular `List` to a lazy `Stream` in MoonBit.  It uses a thunk to delay the conversion of the tail of the list, avoiding immediate computation. This function takes a `List[T]` as input and returns a `Stream[T]`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-1.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn Stream::from_list[T](l : List[T]) -> Stream[T] {
  match l {
    Nil => Empty
    Cons(x, xs) => Cons(x, fn () { Stream::from_list(xs) })
  }
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Method Definition on Function Type Alias (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the E4131 error. It attempts to define a method `call` for a type alias `FuncAlias`, which is an alias for a function type `(Int) -> Unit`. MoonBit does not allow method definitions on type aliases that are function types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4131.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
typealias FuncAlias = (Int) -> Unit

pub fn FuncAlias::call(self : FuncAlias) -> Unit {
  //   ^~~~~~~~~
  // Error: The type alias FuncAlias is a function type, not a type constructor.
  self(0)
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous Example: Loop without Continue (MoonBit)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the compiler error E0018 in MoonBit, where a `loop` expression is used without a `continue` statement, making the loop redundant. The `countdown` function attempts to decrement a counter within a loop, but without `continue`, the loop executes only once.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E0018.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn countdown(n : Int) -> Int {
  let mut count = n
  loop count {
    _..<0 => break
    _ => count = count - 1
  }
  return count
}
```

```
  // Warning: The public modifier is redundant here

}
```

TITLE: Newtype Access Error Example - MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the error that occurs when trying to access a field of a struct directly when it's defined within a struct or enum that is not a newtype. It attempts to access the `value` field of an `Inner` struct within `ErrorOuter` (a type alias, which causes an error) and `EnumOuter` (an enum).
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4136.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
struct Inner {
  value : Int
}

type! ErrorOuter Inner

enum EnumOuter {
  Outer(Inner)
}

fn main {
  let outer : ErrorOuter = ErrorOuter(Inner::{ value: 1 })
  println(outer.value) // Error: This expression has type ErrorOuter, which is a error type type and not a record.
  let outer : EnumOuter = Outer(Inner::{ value: 2 })
  println(outer.value) // Error: This expression has type EnumOuter, which is a variant type and not a record.
}
```

TITLE: Erroneous For-Loop Example (Missing Else)
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates a for-loop used as the return expression of a function with a non-Unit return type, but it lacks the required 'else' branch. This results in the E4108 compiler error. The function 'f' is intended to return an Int, but the for-loop does not explicitly provide a value when it completes normally. Function 'g' exhibits same issue.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4108.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
pub fn f(x: Int) -> Int {
  for i = 0, acc = 0; i < x; i = i + 1, acc = acc + i {
//^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Error: The for loop is
//                                                      not expected to yield a
//                                                      value, please add an
//                                                      `else` branch.
  }
}

pub fn g(x: Int) -> Int {
  for i in 0..=x {
  }
}
```

TITLE: Incorrect op_add implementation in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates an incorrect implementation of the `op_add` method for a custom type `A` in MoonBit. The `op_add` method is intended to overload the `+` operator, but it incorrectly accepts three arguments instead of the expected two, leading to the E4065 error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E4065.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
type A Int

fn A::op_add(self : A, other : A, opt? : A) -> A {
  //  ^~~~~~
  // Error: overloaded operator "op_add" should accept 2 arguments, but it accepts 3 arguments
  let opt = match opt {
    None => 0
    Some(opt) => opt._
  }
  return self._ + other._ + opt
}
```

TITLE: Deprecated Function with Alert in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a deprecated function `greeting()` marked with an alert message recommending the use of `greet()` instead. The `main` function calls `greeting()`, triggering the alert.  The alert is a compile-time warning that suggests migrating to the new `greet` API.  The `/// @alert` annotation is used to specify the alert.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/error_codes/E2000.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
/// @alert deprecated "Use `greet` instead"
fn greeting() -> String {
  "Hello!"
}

fn greet(name~ : String = "") -> String {
  if name != "" {
    "Hello!"
  } else {
    "Hello, \{name}!"
  }
}

fn main {
  println(greeting())
  //      ^~~~~~~~ Warning (Alert deprecated): Use `greet` instead(2000)
}
```

```
}
```

TITLE: Invalid Continue Usage in Loop Initialization - Moonbit

TITLE: Defining Addition Operation for Nodes in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code defines the addition operation between `Node` types, taking into account the abstracted `Data` type. It merges the data of the left and right nodes and sets the resulting tag to `Nil`, indicating that the parent's LazyTag no longer applies to the merged node.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree2.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
trait Op_add[Data, Tag] {
  fn op_add(Data, Data) -> Data
}

impl [Data: Op_add[Data, Tag], Tag] Op_add[Node[Data, Tag], Tag] for Node[Data, Tag] {
  fn op_add(left: Node[Data, Tag], right: Node[Data, Tag]) -> Node[Data, Tag] {
    let left_data = match left {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { data, .. } => data
    }
    let right_data = match right {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { data, .. } => data
    }
    let data = op_add(left_data, right_data)
    Node { left, right, data, tag: Nil, len: 0 }
  }
}
```

```
}
```

TITLE: Infinite Fibonacci sequence in Clojure
DESCRIPTION: This Clojure code defines an infinite Fibonacci sequence using lazy lists. It leverages the `Cons` constructor to build the list, with the first two elements being 0 and 1.  Subsequent elements are generated by zipping the `fibs` list with its tail, adding corresponding elements together.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: clojure
CODE:
```
(defn fibs[] (Cons 0 (Cons 1 (zipWith add fibs (tail fibs)))))
```

TITLE: Unwinding Stack in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This MoonBit code implements the `Unwind` instruction. It checks the node type on the top of the stack. If it's a number (NNum), it checks if there's a recoverable context in the dump. If so, it restores the context. If the node is an application (NApp), it pushes the left child's address onto the stack and continues unwinding. If it's a supercombinator (NAp), it rearranges the stack if necessary and executes the supercombinator's instructions. If it's an indirection node (NInd), update the stack with the address it points to and re-unwind.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-2.md#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
Unwind => {
      let addr = state.stack.last()
      let node = state.heap[addr]
      match node {
        Node::NNum(_) => {
          match list::last_opt(state.dump) {
            Some((old_instrs, old_stack)) => {
              let new_dump = list::drop_last(state.dump)
              {
                state with
                instructions = old_instrs,
                stack = list::push(old_stack, addr),
                dump = new_dump
              }
            }
            None => state // Program completes
          }
        }
        Node::NApp(a1, _) => {
          let new_stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)
          {
            state with
            stack = list::push(new_stack, a1)
          }
        }
        Node::NAp(n, instrs) => {
          let new_state = if n == 0 {
            state
          } else {
            rearrange(state, n)
          }
          {
            new_state with
            instructions = instrs
          }
        }
        Node::NInd(addr2) => {
          let new_stack = list::drop_last(state.stack)
          {
            state with
            stack = list::push(new_stack, addr2)
          }
        }
      }
    }
```

TITLE: Show Implementation for TermDBI in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet implements the `Show` trait for the `TermDBI` enum in MoonBit, allowing Lambda terms represented with de Bruijn indices to be printed and viewed easily.  The implementation recursively prints the structure of the term, using the stored string for variable names to improve readability.

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
impl Show for TermDBI {
  fn show(self : Self) -> String {
    match self {
      VarDBI(i, s) => s + "#" + show(i)
      AbsDBI(s, t) => "(\\ " + s + "." + show(t) + ")"
      AppDBI(t1, t2) => show(t1) + " " + show(t2)
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Take function definition in Clojure
DESCRIPTION: This Clojure code defines a `take` function that takes the first `n` elements of a list `l`. It uses pattern matching with `case` to handle empty lists (`Nil`) and non-empty lists (`Cons x xs`). If `n` is less than or equal to 0, it returns `Nil`; otherwise, it returns a new list containing the first element `x` and the result of recursively calling `take` with `n-1` and the rest of the list `xs`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: clojure
CODE:
```
(defn take[n l]
  (case l
    [(Nil) Nil]
    [(Cons x xs)
      (if (le n 0)
        Nil
        (Cons x (take (sub n 1) xs)))]))
```

TITLE: Building the Segment Tree in MoonBit
DESCRIPTION: This code implements the tree-building function. It recursively constructs the tree from a given array of data.  It creates `Leaf` nodes for single elements and `Node` nodes by combining the results of building subtrees for the left and right halves of the array. The addition operations from the `Op_add` trait are used to calculate data for the parent nodes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/segment-tree/segment-tree2.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn build[Data: Op_add[Data, Tag], Tag](arr: List[Data], l: Int, r: Int) -> Node[Data, Tag] {
  if l == r {
    match arr {
      Cons(x, _) => Leaf(x)
      Nil => panic "unreachable"
    }
  } else {
    let mid = l + (r - l) / 2
    let left = build(arr, l, mid)
    let right = build(arr, mid + 1, r)
    let len = r - l + 1
    let data = match left {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { data, .. } => data
    }
    match right {
      Leaf(data) => data
      Node { data, .. } => data
    }
    Node { left, right, data: op_add(left, right), tag: Nil, len }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing find_path function in Moonbit
DESCRIPTION: This code shows the implementation of the `find_path` function in Moonbit. This function recursively searches for the complete edit path by finding the middle snake using the `midpoint` function.  If no middle snake is found, it returns an empty array, otherwise, it splits the problem into two subproblems and recursively calls `find_path` on them.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/myers-diff/myers-diff3.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
fn find_path(a: Array[String], b: Array[String], box: Box) -> Array[Snake] {
  match midpoint(box, a, b) {
    None => { [] }
    Some(snake) => {
      if snake.px == box.x0 && snake.py == box.y0 {
        let box1 = Box { x0: snake.x, y0: snake.y, x1: box.x1, y1: box.y1 }
        let path1 = find_path(a, b, box1)
        [snake, ..path1]
      } else if snake.x == box.x1 && snake.y == box.y1 {
        let box0 = Box { x0: box.x0, y0: box.y0, x1: snake.px, y1: snake.py }
        let path0 = find_path(a, b, box0)
        [..path0, snake]
      } else {
        let box0 = Box { x0: box.x0, y0: box.y0, x1: snake.px, y1: snake.py }
        let box1 = Box { x0: snake.x, y0: snake.y, x1: box.x1, y1: box.y1 }
        let path0 = find_path(a, b, box0)
        let path1 = find_path(a, b, box1)
        [..path0, snake, ..path1]
      }
    }
  }
}

```

```
      "wasm-gc": {
        "export-memory-name": "memory"
      }
    }
  }
```

LANGUAGE: moonbit

```
let f : fn(Int) -> Int! = fn!(x) { x + 1 }

type! MyError
let x : Error = MyError
```

TITLE: Compile Primitive Functions
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how primitive functions are compiled in MoonBit. It shows the basic structure for defining primitive operations within the compiler. The function takes a `Symbol` and a list of expressions and returns a list of `Instruction`s.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/example/gmachine/gmachine-3.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
match prim with
  | `add =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Add]
  | `sub =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Sub]
  | `mul =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Mul]
  | `div =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Div]
  | `eq =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Eq]
  | `lt =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Lt]
  | `gt =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ [Prim Gt]
  | `if =>
    compileC e1 ++ compileC e2 ++ compileC e3 ++ [Prim If]
  | `negate =>
    compileC e1 ++ [Prim Negate]
  | _ => abort "Unimplemented primitive"
```

TITLE: Moonbit Alert Pragmas Example
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the use of `@alert` pragmas within doc comments in Moonbit.  The `@alert` pragma is used to mark functions as `deprecated` or `unsafe`, providing a mechanism for generating warnings when these functions are referenced.  It takes the form `@alert category "alert message..."`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/language/docs.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: moonbit
CODE:
```
/// @alert deprecated "Use foo2 instead"
pub fn foo() -> Unit {
  ...
}

/// @alert unsafe "Div will cause an error when y is zero"
pub fn div(x : Int, y : Int) -> Int {
  ...
}

test {
  // Warning (Alert deprecated): Use foo2 instead
  foo()
  // Warning (Alert unsafe): Div will cause an error when y is zero
  div(1, 2) |> ignore
}
```

TITLE: Creating and Activating Python Virtual Environment
DESCRIPTION: This snippet creates a Python virtual environment, activates it, and installs the required dependencies from `requirements.txt`. It uses `venv` for environment creation and `pip` for package installation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/README-zh.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
python3 -m venv .env
source .env/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

TITLE: Translation Template Update
DESCRIPTION: This snippet updates the translation template using `make gettext` to extract translatable strings and `sphinx-intl update` to merge them into the existing translation files. This process prepares the documentation for localization.
SOURCE: https://github.com/moonbitlang/moonbit-docs/blob/main/next/README.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
make gettext
sphinx-intl update -p _build/gettext -l zh_CN
```
